qas.question: How were the population factions of the Ottoman Empire classified ?

answers.text: religion was the defining characteristic of national groups

qas.question: What did it mean to be classified as a Greek by the millet command ?

answers.text: was applied by the Ottomans to all members of the Orthodox Church, regardless of their language or ethnic origin.

qas.question: What moniker did the Greeks grant themselves for distinction ?

answers.text: The Greek speakers were the only ethnic group to actually call themselves Romioi

qas.question: What did the literate segment of Greeks consider to be a part of their ethic lines ?

answers.text: those educated, considered their ethnicity (genos) to be Hellenic

qas.question: Were Christian prized among the Ottomans ?

answers.text: second-class status of Christians inherent in the Ottoman millet system

qas.question: How weren't the population factions of the Ottoman Empire classified

plausible_answers.text: the exonym "Greeks" (Rumlar from the name Rhomaioi) was applied by the Ottomans to all members of the Orthodox Church

qas.question: What did it mean to not be classified as a Greek by the millet command ?
What moniker did the Greeks grant themselves for distinction?
What did the literate segment of Greeks consider not to be a part of their ethic lines ?
Were Christian prized among the non-Ottomans

context: For those that remained under the Ottoman Empire's millet system, <a0_0><b5_0>religion<b5_0/> was the defining characteristic of national groups<a0_0/> (milletler), so <b6_0>the exonym "Greeks" (Rumlar from the name Rhomaioi) <a1_0>was applied by the Ottomans to all members of the Orthodox Church<b6_0/>, regardless of their language or ethnic origin.<a1_0/> <a2_0>The Greek speakers were the only ethnic group to actually call themselves <b7_0>Romioi<b7_0/><a2_0/>, (as opposed to being so named by others) and, at least <a3_0>those educated, considered their ethnicity (genos) to be <b8_0>Hellenic<b8_0/><a3_0/>. There were, however, many Greeks who escaped the <a4_0><b9_0>second-class status<b9_0/> of Christians inherent in the Ottoman millet system<a4_0/>, according to which Muslims were explicitly awarded senior status and preferential treatment. These Greeks either emigrated, particularly to their fellow Greek Orthodox protector, the Russian Empire, or simply converted to Islam, often only very superficially and whilst remaining crypto-Christian. The most notable examples of large-scale conversion to Turkish Islam among those today defined as Greek Muslims - excluding those who had to convert as a matter of course on being recruited through the devshirme - were to be found in Crete (Cretan Turks), Greek Macedonia (for example among the Vallahades of western Macedonia), and among Pontic Greeks in the Pontic Alps and Armenian Highlands. Several Ottoman sultans and princes were also of part Greek origin, with mothers who were either Greek concubines or princesses from Byzantine noble families, one famous example being sultan Selim the Grim, whose mother Gülbahar Hatun was a Pontic Greek.
